title: For Loops (Count-Based Repetition)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Three parts separated by semicolons. init runs ONCE at start. condition checked BEFORE each iteration. update runs AFTER each iteration.
Initialization: Creates counter variable. Usually int i = 0 (start at 0) or int i = 1 (start at 1). Variable i only exists in loop!
Increment: Add 1 after each loop. Can also do i-- (subtract), i += 2 (add 2), i *= 2 (double), etc. Controls how to move to next iteration.

syntaxBreakdown.codeSnippet: When to use for vs while
syntaxBreakdown.explanation: FOR: Know iteration count (repeat 10 times, 0 to 99, etc.). WHILE: Unknown count (until user enters 'quit', while balance > 0).

challenge.instructions:
Create a compound interest calculator!

1. Ask for initial investment amount
2. Ask for annual interest rate (as %, like 5 for 5%)
3. Ask for number of years
4. Use for loop to calculate year by year:
   - Formula: amount = amount * (1 + rate/100)
   - Display year number and amount each year
5. Calculate total interest earned
6. Display summary

Example:
Initial: $1000
Rate: 5%
Years: 3

Year 1: $1050.00
Year 2: $1102.50
Year 3: $1157.63

Total interest: $157.63
challenge.hint: for (int year = 1; year <= years; year++) loops for each year. Compound formula: amount = amount * (1 + rate/100). Interest = final - initial. {value:F2} formats money to 2 decimals.
commonStickingPoints: < vs <=: for (i = 0; i < 5) runs 5 times (0-4). for (i = 0; i <= 5) runs 6 times (0-5). for (i = 1; i <= 10) runs 10 times (1-10). Very common off-by-one error!
Starting at 0 vs 1: Arrays start at 0, so for (i = 0; i < arr.Length). Counting 1-10 for humans: for (i = 1; i <= 10). Choose based on use case!
Modifying i inside loop: for (i = 0; i < 10; i++) { i++; } skips numbers! Loop already increments i. Don't modify i inside unless you know what you're doing.
Variable scope: int i in for loop only exists in loop! Can't use i after loop ends. Declare before loop if needed after: int i; for (i = 0; ...).
